levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting forwards from 1 to 20 using concrete objects, touching each object as it is counted (one-to-one correspondence).
levels.example_task: Count these cubes. Touch each cube as you count: 1, 2, 3... How many are there?
common_errors: Skipping an object or counting one object twice (losing one-to-one correspondence)
Saying number names out of order after 12 (e.g. 13, 15, 14)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting forwards and backwards within 50, starting from any given number, using a number line or hundred square for support.
levels.example_task: Start at 27. Count forwards to 35. Now count backwards from 35 to 27.
common_errors: Hesitating or making errors at decade boundaries (e.g. saying 28, 29, 20 instead of 30)
Counting backwards is significantly slower and less fluent than counting forwards

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting forwards and backwards within 100 from any given number, including across decade boundaries, without support.
levels.example_task: Start at 77. Count forwards to 85. Now start at 43 and count backwards to 36.
common_errors: Stumbling at the transition from 79 to 80 or from 40 to 39
Not knowing what comes after 99 when counting forwards to 100

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Counting forwards and backwards across 100 and explaining what happens at decade boundaries.
levels.example_task: Count backwards from 103 to 96. What do you notice happens when you cross 100?
levels.example_response: 103, 102, 101, 100, 99, 98, 97, 96. When you cross 100, the number of digits changes from three to two. The tens digit goes to 9 because 99 is one less than 100.
common_errors: Saying 100, 99, 88 (jumping by 11 instead of 1 after 99)
Being unable to explain the digit change at 100 in their own words

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Counting in 2s from 0 to 20 using pairs of objects (socks, shoes, gloves) as concrete support.
levels.example_task: Put counters into pairs. Count the total as you add each pair: 2, 4, 6... Continue to 20.
common_errors: Reverting to counting in 1s after a few pairs (2, 4, 5, 6...)
Counting in 2s starting from 1 (1, 3, 5, 7...) — confusing odd and even counting

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Counting in 2s, 5s and 10s from 0, using a hundred square or number line with multiples highlighted.
levels.example_task: Count in 5s from 0 to 50 using the hundred square.
common_errors: Mixing up 5s and 10s sequences (saying 5, 10, 20, 30...)
Losing the pattern after 25 and reverting to adding 10 instead of 5

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Counting in 2s, 5s and 10s from 0 or any given multiple, forwards and backwards, without support.
levels.example_task: Count in 10s starting from 30. Stop at 80. Now count backwards in 5s from 35 to 0.
common_errors: Struggling to start from a non-zero multiple (needing to count from 0 first)
Counting backwards in 5s: hesitating at 15 to 10 or 10 to 5

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using skip counting to solve practical problems and explaining connections between the sequences.
levels.example_task: There are 7 gloves on the table. Is 7 a number you say when counting in 2s from 0? How do you know?
levels.example_response: No, because when I count in 2s from 0 I say 2, 4, 6, 8 — I skip 7. Numbers you say when counting in 2s are all even, and 7 is odd.
common_errors: Saying yes because 7 appears on the number line somewhere
Being unable to explain why 7 is not in the sequence beyond 'it just isn't'

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading single-digit numerals 0–9 when shown on cards, and writing them with correct formation.
levels.example_task: I will hold up a number card. Tell me the number. [Shows 7, then 3, then 9]
levels.example_response: Seven. Three. Nine.
common_errors: Confusing 6 and 9 due to orientation similarity
Forming digits backwards (writing 3 as a mirror image)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and writing two-digit numbers to 20, including the teen numbers, using a number line for support.
levels.example_task: Write the number fourteen. Now write the number seventeen.
common_errors: Writing 41 for fourteen (reversing the digits because 'four' is heard first)
Writing 70 for seventeen (confusing teen and ty numbers)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading and writing any number from 0 to 100 in numerals without support.
levels.example_task: Write the numbers fifty-three and eighty-six in numerals.
common_errors: Writing 35 for fifty-three (reversing tens and ones digits)
Writing 806 for eighty-six (expanding eighty as 80 and appending 6)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Reading number words from 1 to 5 when shown on cards, matching them to the correct numeral.
levels.example_task: Match these word cards to the number cards: one, two, three, four, five.
levels.example_response: one = 1, two = 2, three = 3, four = 4, five = 5
common_errors: Confusing 'four' and 'five' because both start with 'f'
Not recognising the word 'three' when written (reading it phonetically as 'th-ree')

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading and writing number words from 1 to 10, using a word wall for spelling support.
levels.example_task: Write the words for 6, 8 and 10.
levels.example_response: six, eight, ten
common_errors: Spelling 'eight' as 'ate' or 'eit'
Spelling 'seven' as 'sevn'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading and writing number words from 1 to 20 independently and correctly.
levels.example_task: Write the words for 12, 15 and 19.
levels.example_response: twelve, fifteen, nineteen
common_errors: Spelling 'twelve' as 'twelv' (missing the silent e)
Spelling 'fifteen' as 'fiveteen' (using the digit word rather than the irregular form)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding one more than a given number within 10 using concrete objects (adding one cube to a group).
levels.example_task: Here are 6 cubes. Add one more. How many now?
levels.example_response: 7. There are 7 cubes now.
common_errors: Recounting all the cubes from 1 instead of counting on from 6
Saying the answer is 6 (not counting the added cube)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Stating one more and one less for numbers up to 20 using a number line for support.
levels.example_task: What is one less than 14? What is one more than 17?
levels.example_response: One less than 14 is 13. One more than 17 is 18.
common_errors: Confusing one more and one less (giving 15 for one less than 14)
Struggling with one less than teen numbers (saying one less than 11 is 1)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Rapidly stating one more and one less for any number up to 100 without support, including across decade boundaries.
levels.example_task: What is one more than 49? What is one less than 70?
levels.example_response: One more than 49 is 50. One less than 70 is 69.
common_errors: Saying one more than 49 is 410 (appending rather than incrementing)
Saying one less than 70 is 60 (subtracting 10 instead of 1)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Explaining what happens to the digits when finding one more or one less at a decade boundary.
levels.example_task: What is one more than 39? Explain why two digits change.
levels.example_response: One more than 39 is 40. The ones digit goes from 9 to 0 because 9 + 1 = 10 ones, which is the same as 1 ten. So the tens digit goes up by 1 from 3 to 4.
common_errors: Knowing the answer (40) but unable to explain why both digits change
Saying 'the 9 becomes a 10' without linking to the tens column

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Placing numbers on a number line from 0 to 10 where every position is marked and labelled.
levels.example_task: Point to where 7 is on this number line from 0 to 10.
levels.example_response: Points to the position marked 7, between 6 and 8.
common_errors: Pointing to 6 or 8 (one position off due to miscounting from 0)
Starting the count from the mark labelled 0 as 'one'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Placing numbers on a number line from 0 to 20 where only every 5th position is labelled (0, 5, 10, 15, 20).
levels.example_task: Place a counter where 13 should be on this number line.
levels.example_response: Places the counter 3 marks after the 10, at the position for 13.
common_errors: Placing the counter at 15 (confusing 13 with the nearest labelled mark)
Counting marks incorrectly between 10 and 15

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Estimating the position of numbers on a number line from 0 to 100 where only the endpoints and midpoint are labelled.
levels.example_task: This number line goes from 0 to 100. The middle is 50. Where would 75 be? Place a mark.
levels.example_response: Places a mark halfway between 50 and 100.
common_errors: Placing 75 too close to 50 or too close to 100
Not understanding that the spacing should be even between numbers

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing two groups of objects and using 'more' and 'less' to describe which group is bigger, with groups of obviously different sizes.
levels.example_task: Here are 2 red cubes and 8 blue cubes. Which colour has more?
levels.example_response: Blue has more cubes. There are more blue cubes than red cubes.
common_errors: Confusing 'more' and 'less' — pointing to the smaller group when asked for more
Using 'bigger' or 'smaller' instead of the mathematical terms

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Comparing two numbers using the words 'more than', 'less than' and 'equal to' without concrete objects.
levels.example_task: Is 9 more than 6 or less than 6?
levels.example_response: 9 is more than 6.
common_errors: Confusing 'more than' with 'most' when only two quantities are compared
Saying '6 is more than 9' (reversing the comparison)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using 'equal to', 'more than', 'less than', 'most' and 'least' correctly to compare and order numbers up to 100.
levels.example_task: Put these numbers in order from least to most: 34, 12, 67, 45. Which is the least? Which is the most?
levels.example_response: 12, 34, 45, 67. 12 is the least. 67 is the most.
common_errors: Confusing 'least' with 'last' and 'most' with 'first'
Ordering by the ones digit rather than by overall value (e.g. putting 12 after 34 because 2 < 4)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Finding pairs that make 5 and 10 using a ten frame and counters.
levels.example_task: Put 3 red counters on the ten frame. How many yellow counters do you need to fill the frame to 10?
levels.example_response: 7 yellow counters. 3 + 7 = 10.
common_errors: Filling the frame incorrectly and counting the empty spaces rather than the needed counters
Getting bonds to 5 correct but struggling with bonds to 10

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recalling number bonds to 10 without concrete support and beginning to learn bonds to 20.
levels.example_task: What goes with 4 to make 10? What goes with 13 to make 20?
levels.example_response: 6 goes with 4 to make 10. 7 goes with 13 to make 20.
common_errors: Knowing bonds to 10 but not transferring to bonds to 20 (not seeing 13 + 7 = 20 as related to 3 + 7 = 10)
Needing to count on from 13 to 20 instead of recalling the fact

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Instant recall of all addition and subtraction bonds within 20, including relating addition bonds to their subtraction inverses.
levels.example_task: What is 8 + 6? What is 14 – 6?
common_errors: Knowing 8 + 6 = 14 but not automatically knowing 14 – 6 = 8
Counting on from 8 rather than recalling the fact (slower, error-prone)

levels.label: greater_depth
levels.description: Using known number bonds to solve related problems and explain relationships between facts.
levels.example_task: If you know 7 + 8 = 15, what other facts do you know? List as many as you can.
levels.example_response: 8 + 7 = 15, 15 – 7 = 8, 15 – 8 = 7. I also know that 17 + 8 = 25 because it is 10 more.
common_errors: Listing only the original fact and its commutative pair, missing the subtraction inverses
Not seeing the connection to derived facts beyond 20

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Combining two groups of objects by pushing them together and counting all to find the total.
levels.example_task: Here are 3 red cubes and 4 blue cubes. Push them together. How many altogether?
levels.example_response: 7. There are 7 cubes altogether. 3 and 4 makes 7.
common_errors: Miscounting when counting all objects from 1 (skipping one or double-counting)
Giving one of the original group sizes as the answer instead of the total

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Representing addition using a number line — counting on from the larger number.
levels.example_task: Use the number line to work out 5 + 3. Start at 5 and count on 3 jumps.
levels.example_response: Start at 5, jump to 6, 7, 8. The answer is 8. 5 + 3 = 8.
common_errors: Starting the count at 5 instead of jumping from 5 (getting 5, 6, 7 = 7 instead of 8)
Not starting from the larger number, making counting on harder (counting 3 + 5 from 3)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving addition problems within 20 using recall or efficient strategies, recording as a number sentence.
levels.example_task: There were 9 children on the bus. 7 more got on. How many children are on the bus now? Write a number sentence.
levels.example_response: 9 + 7 = 16. There are 16 children on the bus.
common_errors: Writing the number sentence incorrectly (e.g. 7 + 9 = 79)
Not recognising that 'more got on' signals addition

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Physically removing objects from a group and counting the remainder for 'take away' problems.
levels.example_task: Here are 8 cubes. Take away 3. How many are left?
levels.example_response: 5. There are 5 cubes left.
common_errors: Counting the removed objects instead of the remaining ones
Taking away the wrong number of objects

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using a number line to count back for take-away problems and count the gap for difference problems.
levels.example_task: Use the number line. Start at 12. Count back 5. What number do you land on?
common_errors: Counting the starting number as a jump (landing on 8 instead of 7)
Counting forwards instead of backwards

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving both take-away and difference problems within 20, choosing an appropriate strategy and recording as a number sentence.
levels.example_task: Ali has 15 stickers. Ben has 9 stickers. How many more stickers does Ali have than Ben?
levels.example_response: 15 – 9 = 6. Ali has 6 more stickers than Ben.
common_errors: Adding instead of subtracting (saying 15 + 9 = 24)
Not recognising 'how many more' as a subtraction/difference problem

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Solving missing number problems with a missing addend using concrete objects: ? + 3 = 7.
levels.example_task: I have some cubes and 3 more cubes. Altogether there are 7. How many cubes did I start with? Use cubes to find out.
levels.example_response: 4. I started with 4 cubes because 4 + 3 = 7.
common_errors: Guessing rather than using objects to work it out
Adding 3 + 7 = 10 instead of finding the missing part

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Solving missing number problems in different positions using a part-whole model: 6 + ? = 11, ? – 4 = 5.
levels.example_task: Fill in the missing number: 6 + ? = 11
levels.example_response: 6 + 5 = 11. The missing number is 5.
common_errors: Writing 6 + 11 = 17 (adding the two visible numbers)
Not knowing how to work backwards from the total

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving missing number problems where the unknown is in any position, understanding = as equivalence.
levels.example_task: Find the missing number: 7 = ? – 9
levels.example_response: 7 = 16 – 9. The missing number is 16 because 16 – 9 = 7.
common_errors: Being confused by the equals sign on the left (thinking 7 = means 'seven equals nothing')
Computing 7 – 9 or 7 + 9 without understanding the structure

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Sharing objects equally between 2 people by dealing one at a time ('one for you, one for me').
levels.example_task: Share 10 cubes equally between 2 teddies. How many does each teddy get?
levels.example_response: Each teddy gets 5 cubes.
common_errors: Giving more cubes to one teddy than the other (unequal sharing)
Dealing in clumps rather than one at a time, leading to uneven groups

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Making equal groups of a given size from a collection (grouping) and counting the number of groups.
levels.example_task: Put these 12 counters into groups of 3. How many groups did you make?
levels.example_response: 4 groups. There are 4 groups of 3 in 12.
common_errors: Making groups of different sizes (not all exactly 3)
Confusing 'groups of 3' with '3 groups' — making 3 groups of 4 instead

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Solving simple grouping and sharing problems and connecting them to multiplication and division language.
levels.example_task: There are 15 pencils. Put them in groups of 5. How many groups? Can you write this as a number sentence?
common_errors: Being able to physically group but unable to connect to the ÷ symbol
Writing the division the wrong way round (5 ÷ 15 instead of 15 ÷ 5)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Doubling numbers to 5 by making two identical groups of objects.
levels.example_task: Make a group of 4 cubes. Now make another group the same size. How many altogether?
levels.example_response: 8. Double 4 is 8 because 4 + 4 = 8.
common_errors: Making two groups of different sizes
Counting all objects from 1 instead of saying the double

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Doubling numbers to 10 and halving even numbers to 20 using pictorial support.
levels.example_task: What is double 7? What is half of 16?
levels.example_response: Double 7 is 14. Half of 16 is 8.
common_errors: Adding 2 instead of doubling (double 7 = 9 instead of 14)
Halving by subtracting 2 instead of dividing by 2 (half of 16 = 14)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Rapidly recalling doubles to 10 and corresponding halves, and recognising halving as the inverse of doubling.
levels.example_task: Double 8 is 16. What is half of 16? How do you know without working it out?
levels.example_response: Half of 16 is 8. I know because halving undoes doubling — if double 8 is 16, then half of 16 must be 8.
common_errors: Knowing double 8 = 16 but working out half of 16 by counting rather than using the inverse
Not recognising halving as the inverse of doubling

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Folding a shape in half and checking that the two parts are the same size by overlaying them.
levels.example_task: Fold this paper circle in half. Are the two parts the same size? How do you know?
levels.example_response: Yes, the two parts are the same size. I can see they match exactly when I fold them on top of each other.
common_errors: Accepting an uneven fold as 'half' because there are two parts
Not checking whether the two parts are equal

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding one half of a small quantity by sharing equally between 2.
levels.example_task: Find half of 8 counters by sharing them equally between 2 plates.
levels.example_response: Half of 8 is 4. Each plate gets 4 counters.
common_errors: Sharing unequally (5 and 3 instead of 4 and 4)
Confusing 'half' with 'take some away' rather than 'share into 2 equal parts'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding one half of shapes, objects and quantities up to 20, identifying when something has or has not been halved correctly.
levels.example_task: Is this shape cut in half? [Shows a rectangle with an unequal cut] Find half of 18.
levels.example_response: No, the shape is not cut in half because the two parts are different sizes. Half of 18 is 9.
common_errors: Accepting any two-part partition as a half without checking equality
Struggling to halve numbers beyond 10 (e.g. half of 18)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Folding a shape into four equal parts by folding in half and then in half again.
levels.example_task: Fold this paper square in half, then in half again. How many parts are there? Are they all the same size?
levels.example_response: There are 4 parts. Yes, they are all the same size. Each part is a quarter.
common_errors: Folding unevenly so that the four parts are not equal
Not understanding that 'quarter' means 4 equal parts

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Finding one quarter of a quantity by sharing equally between 4.
levels.example_task: Find a quarter of 12 by sharing 12 counters equally between 4 plates.
levels.example_response: A quarter of 12 is 3. Each plate gets 3 counters.
common_errors: Sharing between 2 instead of 4 (finding a half instead of a quarter)
Sharing unequally (getting 4, 3, 3, 2 instead of 3, 3, 3, 3)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding one quarter of shapes, objects and quantities up to 20, and connecting a quarter to half of a half.
levels.example_task: Find a quarter of 20. Explain how a quarter relates to a half.
levels.example_response: A quarter of 20 is 5. A quarter is half of a half: half of 20 is 10, half of 10 is 5.
common_errors: Finding a half instead of a quarter (saying quarter of 20 is 10)
Not understanding the relationship between halving twice and quartering

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing two objects by direct comparison, placing them side by side from the same baseline.
levels.example_task: Put these two pencils next to each other, both starting at the same edge of the table. Which is longer?
levels.example_response: The red pencil is longer than the blue pencil.
common_errors: Not aligning the starting points — comparing with one pencil further forward
Confusing 'longer' and 'taller' (using height language for horizontal length)

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Measuring length using non-standard units, ensuring no gaps or overlaps between units.
levels.example_task: Measure the length of this book using cubes. How many cubes long is it?
levels.example_response: The book is 8 cubes long.
common_errors: Leaving gaps between cubes (getting a measurement that is too short)
Overlapping cubes (getting a measurement that is too long)

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Measuring length in centimetres using a ruler, starting from 0 and reading the scale correctly.
levels.example_task: Measure the length of this ribbon using a ruler. How many centimetres long is it?
levels.example_response: The ribbon is 14 centimetres long.
common_errors: Starting from 1 on the ruler instead of 0, giving a measurement that is 1 cm too short
Reading the number at the wrong end of the object

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing two objects by holding one in each hand and saying which feels heavier or lighter.
levels.example_task: Hold the apple in one hand and the pencil in the other. Which is heavier?
levels.example_response: The apple is heavier than the pencil.
common_errors: Confusing size with weight (thinking the bigger object must be heavier)
Using 'bigger' instead of 'heavier'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Using a balance scale to compare two objects, identifying which is heavier by which side goes down.
levels.example_task: Put the toy car on one side of the balance and the rubber on the other. Which is heavier? How do you know?
levels.example_response: The toy car is heavier because its side of the balance goes down.
common_errors: Thinking the side that goes up is the heavier side
Not placing objects carefully on the balance pans

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Measuring mass using non-standard units on a balance scale and beginning to use standard units (g, kg).
levels.example_task: How many cubes does the pencil case balance? Is it heavier or lighter than 20 cubes?
levels.example_response: The pencil case balances 15 cubes. It is lighter than 20 cubes.
common_errors: Miscounting the cubes on the balance
Not understanding that the balance is level when both sides weigh the same

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Comparing two containers using the vocabulary 'full', 'empty' and 'half full' by looking at the water level.
levels.example_task: Look at these two bottles. Which one is full? Which one is half full? Which one is empty?
levels.example_response: The red bottle is full. The blue bottle is half full. The green bottle is empty.
common_errors: Confusing 'full' with 'big' (thinking a large empty container is 'full')
Not understanding that 'half full' means the water is at the halfway mark

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Comparing the capacity of two containers by pouring water from one to the other.
levels.example_task: Pour the water from the tall thin bottle into the short wide bottle. Does it all fit? Which holds more?
levels.example_response: The water does not all fit — some is left over. The tall thin bottle holds more than the short wide bottle.
common_errors: Assuming the taller container always holds more
Spilling water during pouring and drawing incorrect conclusions

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Measuring capacity using non-standard units (cups) and beginning to use standard units (litres).
levels.example_task: How many cups of water does the jug hold? Is it more or less than 5 cups?
levels.example_response: The jug holds 7 cups of water. That is more than 5 cups.
common_errors: Not filling the cup to the same level each time, giving inconsistent measurements
Losing count of the number of cups poured

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Sequencing daily events using time vocabulary: before, after, morning, afternoon.
levels.example_task: Put these picture cards in order: eating breakfast, going to bed, eating lunch. Which comes first?
levels.example_response: Eating breakfast, then eating lunch, then going to bed. Breakfast comes first because it happens in the morning.
common_errors: Putting lunch before breakfast
Not knowing whether 'afternoon' is before or after 'morning'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Reading o'clock times on an analogue clock by identifying the position of the short (hour) hand.
levels.example_task: What time does this clock show? [Clock shows 3 o'clock]
levels.example_response: 3 o'clock. The short hand points to 3 and the long hand points to 12.
common_errors: Reading the long hand instead of the short hand (saying 12 o'clock)
Confusing the hour and minute hands when they are similar lengths

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Reading o'clock and half past times on an analogue clock and drawing hands to show given times.
levels.example_task: What time does this clock show? [Clock shows half past 7] Draw the hands for half past 4.
levels.example_response: Half past 7. The short hand is between 7 and 8, and the long hand points to 6. [Draws hour hand between 4 and 5, minute hand at 6]
common_errors: Reading half past 7 as half past 6 (reading the number the hour hand has passed rather than the next number)
Drawing the hour hand pointing exactly at 4 for half past 4 (it should be between 4 and 5)

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Sorting real coins by denomination and naming the most common coins (1p, 2p, 5p, 10p).
levels.example_task: Sort these coins into piles. What is each pile?
levels.example_response: This pile is 1p coins. This pile is 2p coins. This pile is 5p coins. This pile is 10p coins.
common_errors: Confusing 1p and 2p coins (similar copper colour)
Sorting by size rather than by value

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Naming all coins (1p, 2p, 5p, 10p, 20p, 50p, £1, £2) and all notes (£5, £10, £20) and stating their values.
levels.example_task: Name this coin and tell me how much it is worth. [Shows 50p, then £2]
levels.example_response: That is a 50 pence coin. It is worth 50p. That is a 2 pound coin. It is worth £2.
common_errors: Thinking the 5p coin is worth more than the 2p because it is physically larger
Not recognising the £2 coin as different from the £1 coin

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Finding given totals using different combinations of coins.
levels.example_task: Make 20p using exactly 3 coins.
common_errors: Using the right number of coins but the wrong total (e.g. 10p + 5p + 2p = 17p)
Not realising that 20p can be made in many different ways

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising and naming circles, triangles and rectangles when shown in their standard orientation.
levels.example_task: What shape is this? [Shows a standard equilateral triangle pointing up, a circle, a landscape rectangle]
levels.example_response: Triangle. Circle. Rectangle.
common_errors: Calling all four-sided shapes 'squares'
Not recognising a square as a type of rectangle

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Recognising shapes in different orientations and sizes, including non-prototypical examples.
levels.example_task: Is this a triangle? [Shows a triangle pointing to the right, not upward]
levels.example_response: Yes, it is still a triangle because it has 3 straight sides and 3 corners, even though it is pointing sideways.
common_errors: Saying a triangle that points sideways or downward 'is not a triangle'
Identifying shapes only by appearance, not by properties

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Naming rectangles (including squares), circles and triangles, describing why they are that shape using the number of sides and corners.
levels.example_task: How do you know this is a rectangle and not a triangle?
levels.example_response: It is a rectangle because it has 4 straight sides and 4 corners. A triangle only has 3 sides and 3 corners.
common_errors: Describing shapes by colour or size rather than by mathematical properties
Not recognising that a square is a special kind of rectangle

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Recognising and naming a sphere, cube and cuboid by handling solid shapes.
levels.example_task: Find the sphere, the cube and the cuboid from this group of shapes.
levels.example_response: This is the sphere (ball shape). This is the cube (all faces are squares). This is the cuboid (box shape).
common_errors: Calling a cube a 'square' (confusing 2-D name with 3-D shape)
Confusing a sphere and a cylinder (both are 'round')

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Naming spheres, cubes, cuboids, pyramids and cylinders, and connecting them to everyday objects.
levels.example_task: What 3-D shape is a cereal box? What about a football? What about a tin of beans?
levels.example_response: A cereal box is a cuboid. A football is a sphere. A tin of beans is a cylinder.
common_errors: Calling a tin of beans 'a circle' (naming the 2-D face rather than the 3-D shape)
Calling a pyramid 'a triangle'

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing 3-D shapes using informal properties: whether they roll, stack, slide, and the shapes of their faces.
levels.example_task: Why can a sphere roll but a cube cannot?
levels.example_response: A sphere is curved all the way round so it rolls easily. A cube has flat faces and sharp corners so it does not roll — it slides or stays still.
common_errors: Saying a cylinder cannot roll (it can roll on its curved surface)
Describing shapes only by name without reference to their properties

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Using 'in front of', 'behind', 'above', 'below' and 'next to' to describe where an object is, using real objects in the classroom.
levels.example_task: Where is the teddy? [Teddy is on top of the cupboard]
levels.example_response: The teddy is above the cupboard. It is on top of the cupboard.
common_errors: Using everyday language ('up there') instead of the mathematical position words
Confusing 'above' and 'below'

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Following and giving instructions using positional language including left, right, forwards and backwards.
levels.example_task: Direct your partner to the treasure: use the words forwards, backwards, left and right.
levels.example_response: Go forwards 3 steps. Turn right. Go forwards 2 steps. The treasure is on your left.
common_errors: Confusing left and right
Giving directions from their own perspective rather than the walker's perspective

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Using the full range of positional vocabulary accurately in spoken and written descriptions, including 'between', 'inside', 'outside'.
levels.example_task: Describe where each animal is in this picture using position words.
levels.example_response: The cat is between the dog and the bird. The fish is inside the bowl. The rabbit is outside the fence, behind the tree.
common_errors: Omitting 'between' and using two separate statements instead
Using 'in' instead of 'inside' or 'out' instead of 'outside'

levels.label: entry
levels.description: Making whole and half turns by physically turning their body, with teacher modelling.
levels.example_task: Stand up. Make a whole turn. Which way are you facing now? Now make a half turn.
levels.example_response: After a whole turn I am facing the same way as before. After a half turn I am facing the opposite direction.
common_errors: Confusing a half turn with a quarter turn (stopping too early)
Not returning to the same direction after a whole turn

levels.label: developing
levels.description: Making quarter and three-quarter turns clockwise and anticlockwise, describing the direction of the turn.
levels.example_task: Face the door. Make a quarter turn clockwise. What are you facing now?
levels.example_response: I am now facing the window. A quarter turn clockwise turned me from the door to the window.
common_errors: Not knowing which direction is clockwise
Making a half turn instead of a quarter turn

levels.label: expected
levels.description: Describing turns precisely as whole, half, quarter or three-quarter turns, clockwise or anticlockwise, and explaining that a quarter turn clockwise reaches the same position as a three-quarter turn anticlockwise.
levels.example_task: I am facing North. I make a quarter turn clockwise. Which direction do I face? What other turn gives the same result?
levels.example_response: I face East. A three-quarter turn anticlockwise also ends facing East.
common_errors: Not understanding that different turns can arrive at the same facing direction
Confusing clockwise and anticlockwise
